# Chief Intelligence Officer - Daily Brief
**Topic**: Latest global political and military news
**Time**: 2026/2/18 16:49

## Situation Overview
Welcome to the Daily News Channel, I'm Joe. Today is February 18, 2026. In the past 24 hours, the global diplomatic and security landscape has undergone unprecedented upheaval. From secret diplomacy on the shores of Lake Geneva in Switzerland to live-fire military exercises in the Strait of Hormuz, the map of the international order is being reshaped by deep competition among major powers. This program will review 20 major events that have impacted global processes in the past 24 hours, offering insights into the strategic intentions behind these complex news stories. We will focus on the nuclear negotiations between the US and Iran, which have an ultimatum-like quality, as well as the subtle ties established between the US and Russia as their arms control treaty expires, and the significant shift in the Indo-Pacific security architecture following political changes. Faced with this volatile geopolitical situation, please follow our in-depth reporting to analyze the profound impact of each key decision on the global future.

## Key Intelligence
### 1. US Presidential Envoy Launches "Dual-Track Diplomacy" in Geneva: Simultaneous Consultations on the Iranian Nuclear Issue and the Russia-Ukraine Situation
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: CNN, Intelligence Online, Vision Times
- **Summary**: According to CNN and several intelligence analysis agencies, US Presidential Envoy Jared Kushner and Sergei Vitkov held high-level, back-to-back secret talks in Geneva on February 17. In the morning, the US delegation met with Iranian officials at the Omani consulate in Geneva, with the core issue revolving around restrictions on Iran's nuclear infrastructure and ballistic missile program. Then, in the afternoon, the US shifted to coordination with representatives from Russia and Ukraine. Observers point out that this "dual-track" diplomatic approach is extremely rare, indicating that the Trump administration is attempting to link the Middle East situation with the European conflict in a holistic strategy, seeking a comprehensive agreement that includes containing Hezbollah and Hamas in Lebanon.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-administration-iran-talks-02-17-26)
  - [2] [Intelligence Online](https://www.intelligenceonline.com/)
  - [3] [Vision Times](https://www.visiontimes.com/2026/02/17/china-adjusts-its-ukraine-stance-seeking-balance-between-aid-and-backing-russia.html)

### 2. The joint military exercises between China, Russia, and Iran have entered a critical phase, and tensions in the Strait of Hormuz have escalated again.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: Defence Security Asia, CNN, Wikipedia
- **Summary**: According to *Asia Defense & Security*, Iran closed part of the Strait of Hormuz on the 17th to facilitate a naval exercise codenamed "Smart Control" conducted by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard. Simultaneously, China, Russia, and Iran held the "Security Link 2026" joint naval exercise. The US Central Command issued a warning, deeming the activities "unsafe," and urgently deployed a carrier strike group to the region. The report indicates that although China and Russia intend to challenge Western maritime hegemony through their military exercises, all parties remain cautious about a direct confrontation with the US military over the Iranian issue. As a result, countries heavily reliant on this waterway, such as Japan and India, have strengthened their real-time monitoring of the situation.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Defence Security Asia](https://defencesecurityasia.com/en/russia-china-iran-maritime-security-belt-2026-strait-of-hormuz-us-carrier-strike-group/)
  - [2] [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-administration-iran-talks-02-17-26)
  - [3] [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_United_States_military_buildup_in_the_Middle_East)

### 3. Trump confirmed direct communication with China, covering sensitive issues such as arms sales to Taiwan.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: Japan Times, Millennium Post
- **Summary**: According to The Japan Times, US President Trump confirmed on February 16 that he was in direct communication with Chinese leaders regarding future plans to sell weapons to Taiwan. Trump stated that a final decision is expected before the summit in April. Meanwhile, China and Russia have reached an agreement to further deepen military and technological cooperation to counter the shift in US strategic focus. Although high-level communication channels between China and the US have been initially restored, the report points out that both sides are still actively delineating a "strategic border" in the region to prevent structural competition from escalating into direct military friction.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Japan Times](https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2026/02/17/asia-pacific/politics/trump-taiwan-arms-sales-xi-china/)
  - [2] [Millennium Post](https://www.millenniumpost.in/world/china-and-russia-agree-to-deepen-military-ties-amid-us-strategy-shift-645867)

### 4. US military seizes Russian-protected oil tanker in British waters; "Abraham Accord 2.0" expands into Central Asia.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: New York Times, Modern Diplomacy
- **Summary**: According to The New York Times, the U.S. military recently seized an oil tanker named "Marinera" in waters near Britain. The ship had previously claimed to be under Russian protection. This action is seen as part of a U.S. strategy to isolate the "Russian-Chinese axis." On the diplomatic front, the Trump administration is pushing for the expansion of the "Abraham Accords 2.0" into Central Asia and Southeast Asia, with Kazakhstan listed as a key target, aiming to counter China's strategic influence in the region. However, the report also mentions that the U.S. currently faces challenges in integrating intelligence resources to address joint Sino-Russian expeditions in the Arctic.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/live/2026/02/17/us/trump-news)
  - [2] [Modern Diplomacy](https://moderndiplomacy.eu/2026/02/17/abraham-accords-and-their-impact-on-chinese-national-security/)

### 5. Conflict escalates on the Gaza-Lebanon border, with Israeli airstrikes killing several militants.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: BBC News, Al Arabiya English
- **Summary**: According to the BBC, Israel has continued to escalate its military operations in the Gaza Strip and along the Lebanese border over the past 24 hours. Israeli airstrikes in Gaza have killed at least 11 Palestinians, including several militants. In Lebanon, an Israeli drone precisely struck a car in Majdar Anjar, Bekaa province, near the Syrian border, targeting members of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ). The attack resulted in the deaths of all four people inside the vehicle. This escalating tensions in the Middle East have raised international concerns about further spillover effects from the conflict.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Wikipedia (BBC News, Al Arabiya English)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events)

### 6. The U.S. military has developed a multi-week operational plan targeting Iranian infrastructure, pushing military pressure to its limit.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: AceComments (mu.nu)
- **Summary**: According to AceComments, citing internal sources, US military planners have developed a detailed operational plan against Iran, based on potential White House directives. This plan not only covers traditional nuclear facilities but also significantly extends to Iranian state institutions and critical security infrastructure. The report indicates that the military operation is expected to last for several weeks and aims to completely cripple Iran's strategic retaliatory capabilities. Currently, the US is using this "maximum pressure" posture to gain leverage in indirect negotiations in Geneva.
- **References**:
  - [1] [AceComments](http://acecomments.mu.nu/?post=387226?utm_source=akdart)

### 7. Sanae Takaichi's election victory marks a new era in Japan's security landscape and will accelerate cooperation with Australia under the AUKUS framework.
- **Time**: 2026-02-18
- **Source**: United States Studies Centre (USSC)
- **Summary**: According to a recent analysis by the University of Sydney's Centre for American Studies, Sanae Takaichi's victory in Japanese politics has become a turning point in the Indo-Pacific security landscape. After taking office, Takaichi is expected to significantly accelerate cooperation between Japan and Australia in key mineral and natural gas sectors. Of particular note is Japan's plan to deeply participate in the development of emerging technologies such as hypersonic weapons under the AUKUS "second pillar." Furthermore, the Japanese government is working to bring forward its defense spending target to 2% of GDP by 2027 and to promote deeper collaboration between its "Mogami-class" destroyers and the Australian Navy, aiming to build a more deterrent regional collective security system.
- **References**:
  - [1] [United States Studies Centre](https://www.ussc.edu.au/sanae-takaichi-landslide-a-turning-point-for-indo-pacific-allies)

### 8. Modi and Macron met in Mumbai, and India and France signed more than 20 strategic cooperation agreements.
- **Time**: 2026-02-18
- **Source**: The Pioneer
- **Summary**: According to The Herald, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and French President Emmanuel Macron held a productive high-level meeting in Mumbai. The two sides announced the launch of the "India-France Year of Innovation" and signed more than 20 bilateral cooperation agreements covering defense, energy, and high-tech fields. As key participants in the Quad (Quad) security dialogue, India's deep collaboration with France aims to enhance its strategic autonomy in the Indo-Pacific region. Observers believe that the warming of Indo-France relations reflects how regional powers are using diversified alliances to address the uncertainties brought about by great power competition and jointly promote the multipolar development of the Indo-Pacific.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The Pioneer](https://dailypioneer.com/uploads/2026/epaper/february/delhi-english-edition-2026-02-18.pdf)

### 9. The U.S. Department of Defense has released its fiscal year 2026 budget, highlighting a surge in IT and AI spending and a focus on electronic warfare superiority.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: The Star, Globe and Mail
- **Summary**: According to the latest Pentagon data cited by The Globe and Mail, the U.S. Department of Defense's total IT budget for fiscal year 2026 has reached $66 billion. The Army's spending on artificial intelligence has increased significantly by 38.3%, while the Air Force's spending on force application-related funding has increased by a staggering 143.8%. Furthermore, Congress has passed an $839 billion defense spending bill, allocating $760 million specifically for the purchase of F-35 fighter jets and investing $474 million to strengthen the development of the EA-37B electronic warfare aircraft. This budget direction clearly indicates that the U.S. military is accelerating its transformation from traditional warfare capabilities to AI-centric intelligent warfare.
- **References**:
  - [1] [The Star](https://www.thestar.com/globenewswire/ai-and-electronic-warfare-are-rewriting-the-rules-of-modern-defense/article_dc85102f-bcaa-5331-b186-d66e98d564a8.html)
  - [2] [Globe and Mail](https://www.theglobeandmail.com/investing/markets/stocks/LHX/pressreleases/36863082/speed-superiority-us-defense-spending-surges-for-hypersonics-and-rapid-launch/)

### 10. Canada's defense market strategy shifts focus to hypersonic weapons and quantum computing over the next eight years.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: LinkedIn
- **Summary**: According to the latest industry analysis report, the Canadian Department of National Defence has identified its strategic focus for 2026-2033 as the comprehensive integration of a next-generation hypersonic defense system. Canada is working to develop an AI-based autonomous decision-making system to enable real-time mission adaptation. The report specifically emphasizes that leveraging quantum computing to enhance defense systems and developing hypersonic countermeasures technologies will be key pillars of its strategy. This shift marks a formal transition of Canadian defense forces from basic research to operational deployment, aiming to ensure adequate preparedness in the increasingly complex Arctic and global geopolitical environment.
- **References**:
  - [1] [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/canada-hypersonic-weapons-market-key-innovations-trends-ai-impact-xyadc/)

### 11. The US-Russia nuclear arms control treaty has officially expired, and both sides have agreed to restore high-level military communication channels.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: BBC News, AP, swissinfo
- **Summary**: According to the BBC, the New START Treaty, the last legal constraint between the US and Russia limiting nuclear arsenals, officially expired on February 17. At this critical juncture, a slight cooling of relations emerged: the US and Russia agreed to re-establish high-level military communications channels. This marks the first restoration of these channels since their closure in 2021. Observers believe that resuming direct dialogue during an arms control vacuum is crucial to preventing accidental conflict due to miscalculation. Despite persistent structural contradictions, this move is seen as a last "firewall" for managing crises.
- **References**:
  - [1] [BBC News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/February_2026)
  - [2] [AP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/February_2026)

### 12. The US and Iran maintain a hardline stance in the Geneva nuclear negotiations, and the US military has deployed 50 fighter jets to the conflict zone.
- **Time**: 2026-02-18
- **Source**: New Indian Express, Hindustan Times
- **Summary**: According to The New Indian Express, the indirect nuclear talks between the US and Iran in Geneva have had a difficult start. Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei stated that the US is incapable of destroying Iran, adopting a hardline stance. Meanwhile, demonstrations against the negotiations broke out in front of the UN office in Geneva. Information obtained by this station indicates that within 24 hours of the talks, the US military deployed 50 advanced fighter jets to relevant sea and air areas. This strategy of "diplomatic maneuvering combined with military intimidation" has led to a wait-and-see attitude from the outside world regarding whether the talks can achieve substantial results.
- **References**:
  - [1] [New Indian Express](https://www.newindianexpress.com/news_sitemap.xml)
  - [2] [Hindustan Times](https://www.hindustantimes.com/bangla/sitemap/news.xml)

### 13. The UN Security Council Sanctions Committee on North Korea approved waivers for 17 humanitarian projects.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: Reuters
- **Summary**: According to Reuters, the UN Security Council's sanctions committee on North Korea has formally approved waivers for 17 humanitarian aid projects targeting North Korea. This move aims to allow international non-governmental organizations to bypass current sanctions restrictions and deliver urgently needed aid and basic public services to North Korea. While sanctions against North Korea's nuclear program remain stringent, these waivers are seen as a balancing effort by the international community to alleviate the humanitarian crisis under the severe sanctions environment.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Reuters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Current_events/February_2026)

### 14. Eighty countries and organizations worldwide issued a joint statement urging the implementation of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
- **Time**: 2026-02-18
- **Source**: Sadanews
- **Summary**: According to Sadanews, representatives from 80 countries and international organizations recently issued a strong joint statement condemning Israel's unilateral decision. The statement reiterated that the only way to achieve lasting peace in the Middle East is through the full implementation of relevant UN resolutions and the concrete advancement of the two-state solution. Representatives called on the international community to protect the Palestinian people's right to self-determination, demanded an immediate halt to the policy of illegal settlement expansion in the occupied territories since 1967, and emphasized the need to seek a long-term, stable solution within the framework of international law.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Sadanews](https://www.sadanews.ps/en/news/276991.html)

### 15. RAND Corporation Symposium: Leadership in the AI Era â€“ Focusing on the Challenges of Biosafety and General Artificial Intelligence
- **Time**: 2026-02-18
- **Source**: RAND Corporation
- **Summary**: According to the RAND Corporation, Senior Fellow Michael Mazar hosted an online seminar on "National Power in the Age of AI" on the 18th. The seminar focused on how artificial intelligence (AI) can reshape global leadership and warned that while AI improves research efficiency, it also increases biosafety risks, such as the lowering of the threshold for modifying viruses. Participants also discussed in depth whether Europe is institutionally prepared for the arrival of artificial general intelligence (AGI). The seminar pointed out that future great power competition will not only be a contest of computing power but also a competition of the ability to govern the risks of AI.
- **References**:
  - [1] [RAND Corporation](https://www.rand.org/topics/artificial-intelligence.html)

### 16. A joint operation in the Caribbean struck a terrorist-linked vessel, and a joint Sino-Russian expedition in the Arctic has drawn attention.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: AceComments, New York Times
- **Summary**: According to multiple media reports, the joint task force codenamed "Southern Spear" recently took decisive action in the Caribbean Sea, striking a vessel believed to be linked to terrorist organizations. Meanwhile, on the other side of the world, in the Arctic region, joint scientific expeditions by China and Russia near Alaska and Greenland are drawing intense attention from the United States. Reports indicate that as Arctic ice melts, the region's strategic value is increasingly evident, and competition among major powers for Arctic scientific research is seen as a prelude to future resource and sovereignty disputes.
- **References**:
  - [1] [AceComments](http://acecomments.mu.nu/?post=387226?utm_source=akdart)
  - [2] [The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/live/2026/02/17/us/trump-news)

### 17. The Chinese and Russian leaders held a video conference, deepening their military-technical alliance and proposing the establishment of a "peace commission."
- **Time**: 2026-02-04
- **Source**: Brasil de Fato / YouTube
- **Summary**: According to reports from this station, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese leaders recently held a video conference, formally confirming an unprecedented level of military and technological cooperation between the two countries. According to Brasil de Fato and related video materials, Moscow and Beijing are discussing the establishment of a parallel body called a "Peace Commission," intended as a supplement to or even an alternative to the United Nations, to address the ongoing escalation of US military deployments. Observers point out that this development signifies that China and Russia are not only binding each other on hard power but also beginning to jointly challenge the existing Western-dominated framework in the international governance system. Both sides emphasized that this strategic cooperation is a stabilizer for addressing global security uncertainties.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Brasil de Fato](https://www.brasildefato.com.br/2026/02/02/china-and-russia-strengthen-alliance-amid-u-s-military-escalation/)
  - [2] [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TNozR854NsQ)

### 18. Reports indicate that China may increase the depth of its aid to the Russia-Ukraine conflict in 2026.
- **Time**: 2026-02-15
- **Source**: EADaily / Bloomberg
- **Summary**: According to a recent report by Bloomberg cited by EADaily, as the Russia-Ukraine conflict enters a critical phase in 2026, China is highly likely to further increase its support for Russia this year. The report analyzes that despite continued pressure from Western sanctions, Beijing is adjusting the scale of its aid based on considerations of global strategic competition. The report points out that this support is not limited to economic and trade resilience but may also involve deeper supply chain integration. This move has raised serious concerns among NATO member states, with US officials stating they are closely monitoring related logistics and financial flows to assess its potential substantive impact on the front lines.
- **References**:
  - [1] [EADaily](https://eadaily.com/en/news/2026/02/15/china-will-increase-assistance-to-russia-in-the-ukrainian-conflict-bloomberg)

### 19. The New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty has officially expired, leaving nuclear arms control among the US, China, and Russia in a stalemate.
- **Time**: 2026-02-05
- **Source**: Reuters / TASS
- **Summary**: According to Reuters and TASS, the Chinese Foreign Ministry recently expressed deep concern and regret over the expiration of the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START). With the treaty officially null and void, Moscow has made it clear that Russia will no longer be bound by the original verification and restriction obligations. Meanwhile, the US State Department confirmed that the US is strongly urging China to join a future trilateral strategic dialogue to build a new global nuclear balance. China reiterated that nuclear powers should bear special responsibilities. Currently, the transparency of the world's major nuclear arsenals has fallen to its lowest level since the Cold War, and the international community is widely concerned that this could trigger a new round of global arms race.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-says-expiration-us-russia-arms-treaty-regrettable-2026-02-05/)
  - [2] [TASS](https://tass.com/world/2088061)

### 20. As US-China relations enter a critical phase in 2026, the situation in Taiwan Province faces a boiling point test.
- **Time**: 2026-02-10
- **Source**: POLITICO / Invezz / The Diplomat
- **Summary**: According to predictions from Politico and multiple defense experts, 2026 will be the most fragile year in the history of US-China relations. Analysis indicates that the risk of conflict involving Taiwan is nearing a boiling point. Despite this, according to The Diplomat, communication channels between Chinese leaders and Trump have been initially restored, attempting to find a mechanism to avoid conflict amidst the turbulent waves of economic decoupling and regional military confrontation. Furthermore, it has been observed that the US military footprint around Taiwan is being redeployed, attempting to maintain deterrence while addressing the uncertainty brought about by internal political fluctuations. Experts warn that any minor miscalculation could escalate into an irreparable military crisis in 2026.
- **References**:
  - [1] [POLITICO](https://www.politico.com/news/2025/12/26/china-u-s-relations-could-fracture-2026-00703020)
  - [2] [Invezz](https://invezz.com/news/2025/12/31/why-2026-could-be-the-year-us-china-tensions-over-taiwan-reach-boiling-point/)
  - [3] [The Diplomat](https://thediplomat.com/2025/12/what-will-2026-bring-for-china-us-relations/)

### 21. Iran, China, and Russia announced a joint naval exercise called "Security Link" in the Indian Ocean.
- **Time**: 2026-01-31
- **Source**: PressTV
- **Summary**: According to PressTV, Iran, China, and Russia recently announced a joint military exercise called "Maritime Security Link" in the Indian Ocean. The exercise aims to strengthen cooperation among the three parties in combating piracy, terrorism, and maritime search and rescue. However, against the backdrop of global tensions, the exercise is widely interpreted as a strategic response to the US military presence in the region. Reports indicate that the number and technological level of participating ships have increased compared to previous years, reflecting the coordinated intentions of key Eurasian powers in strategic waterways in the face of shared geopolitical pressures.
- **References**:
  - [1] [PressTV](https://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2026/01/31/763257/Iran-China-Russia-hold-joint-naval-exercise-Indian-Ocean-Maritime-Security-Belt-tensions-US)

### 22. Beware of escalating war propaganda: The US and UK are accused of replicating propaganda tactics used against Iran.
- **Time**: 2026-02-17
- **Source**: Moon of Alabama
- **Summary**: An analysis report published by the independent investigative media outlet "The Alabama Month" indicates that the US and UK governments have recently exhibited clear pre-war mobilization characteristics in their public discourse. The report points out that negative narratives about Iran in mainstream Western media are being replicated in a "production-line" manner, strikingly similar to the propaganda pattern employed before the Iraq War. The analysis suggests that this propaganda offensive aims to pave the way for further NATO military intervention in the Middle East. The report warns the international community to be vigilant about the role of disinformation in escalating regional tensions and calls for a highly independent observation of the "war logic" disseminated by Western intelligence agencies.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Moon of Alabama](https://www.moonofalabama.org/2026/02/duplicate-propaganda-for-war-on-iran.html)

### 23. Strategic Trade-offs Amid Geopolitical Disorder: The US Navy's Dilemma Between Venezuela and the Indo-Pacific
- **Time**: 2026-02-01
- **Source**: ChinaRussiaReport
- **Summary**: According to an in-depth analysis report released by ChinaRussiaReport Substack, geopolitical disorder in 2026 is forcing the US Navy to make difficult resource trade-offs. The report shows that with the escalating situation in Venezuela and the continued increase in military pressure in the Indo-Pacific region, the US military's power allocation across two strategic directions has reached a critical point. This predicament of being unable to attend to both sides provides a broader window of opportunity for China and Russia to act within their respective spheres of influence. The analysis points out that the US is facing the most serious challenge to global sea control since World War II, and the gap between its strategic resources and its global hegemonic goals is rapidly widening, which has profound strategic implications for the decision-makers in Moscow and Beijing.
- **References**:
  - [1] [ChinaRussiaReport](https://chinarussiareport.substack.com/p/geopolitical-disorder-in-2026-and)

### 24. Collapse of European security architecture: Risk of direct conflict between NATO and Russia surges
- **Time**: 2026-03-01
- **Source**: Foreign Affairs
- **Summary**: A recent academic review article published in *Foreign Affairs* warns that the likelihood of direct conflict between NATO and Russia has significantly increased with the complete collapse of the European security architecture. The article points out that the troop deployments of both sides along the border have reached a point of imminent confrontation, and any friction on the front lines could escalate into a full-scale war across Europe through a chain reaction. Experts believe that due to the lack of an effective crisis communication mechanism, this risk of war caused by structural contradictions has become one of the greatest threats to global peace in 2026, and call on all parties to immediately establish a new emergency collision avoidance mechanism to prevent the situation from spiraling out of control.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Foreign Affairs](https://www.foreignaffairs.com/russia/europes-next-war-charap-haukkala)

### 25. Strategic Endurance Game: China and Russia May Avoid Direct Conflict with the United States Over Iran
- **Time**: 2026-02-18
- **Source**: Barron's
- **Summary**: According to a recent policy analysis published by Barron's, despite the high degree of coordination among China, Russia, and Iran in military exercises and diplomacy, policy experts generally believe that Russia and China will strive to avoid a direct head-on military conflict with the United States over the Iran issue at this stage. The analysis shows that Moscow and Beijing prefer to use asymmetric means and economic leverage to counter the US military threat rather than directly getting involved in a Middle East conflict. This cautious strategic endurance reflects that, in the complex international situation of 2026, both countries will prioritize protecting their core interests and maintaining strategic maneuvering, avoiding falling into the trap of a large-scale regional war.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Barron's](https://www.barrons.com/news/russia-china-unlikely-to-back-iran-against-us-military-threat-8850e6f6)
